Message.Issue: Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'HotMouse1.GetCursorPos(ref HotMouse1.Win32Point)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'HotMouse1.mouse_event(int, int, int, int, int)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.

As it is declared in your code, parameter 'dwExtraInfo' of P/Invoke 'HotMouse1.mouse_event(int, int, int, int, int)' will be 4 bytes wide on 64-bit platforms. This is not correct, as the actual native declaration of this API indicates it should be 8 bytes wide on 64-bit platforms. Consult the MSDN Platform SDK documentation for help determining what data type should be used instead of 'int'.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'HotMouse1.SetCursorPos(int, int)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'Listener.CallNextHookEx(IntPtr, int, IntPtr, IntPtr)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'Listener.GetModuleHandle(string)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.

To reduce security risk, marshal parameter 'lpModuleName' as Unicode, by setting DllImport.CharSet to CharSet.Unicode, or by explicitly marshaling the parameter as UnmanagedType.LPWStr. If you need to marshal this string as ANSI or system-dependent, set BestFitMapping=false; for added security, also set ThrowOnUnmappableChar=true.

Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'Listener.SetWindowsHookEx(int, Listener.LowLevelKeyboardProc, IntPtr, uint)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'Listener.UnhookWindowsHookEx(IntPtr)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.

Rule.Name: Move P/Invokes to NativeMethods class
Rule.Description: This type contains members with the DllImport attribute. Members with the DllImport attribute should be contained in classes named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Rule.Resolution: Because it is a P/Invoke method, {0} should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.

Rule.Name: P/Invoke declarations should be portable
Rule.Resolution: As it is declared in your code, parameter {0} of P/Invoke {1} will be {2} bytes wide on {3} platforms. This is not correct, as the actual native declaration of this API indicates it should be {4} bytes wide on {3} platforms. Consult the MSDN Platform SDK documentation for help determining what data type should be used instead of {5}.

Rule.Name: Specify marshaling for P/Invoke string arguments
Rule.Description: When marshaling strings as ANSI (or as Auto on Win9x), some characters may be changed. If best-fit mapping is on, strings that appear different in Unicode will be marshaled to identical ANSI strings, which may lead to incorrect security decisions. Turning best-fit mapping off reduces this risk, as all characters without equivalents are mapped to '?'. Also, note that CharSet.Ansi is the default setting for all string marshaling; Unicode marshaling must be specified explicitly, either as a CharSet setting of DllImport or StructLayout, or as a MarshalAs attribute with a Unicode (or system-dependent) UnmanagedType.
Rule.Resolution: To reduce security risk, marshal parameter {0} as Unicode, by setting DllImport.CharSet to CharSet.Unicode, or by explicitly marshaling the parameter as UnmanagedType.LPWStr. If you need to marshal this string as ANSI or system-dependent, set BestFitMapping=false; for added security, also set ThrowOnUnmappableChar=true.
